Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Data-driven Demand Response Recommendation System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to provide a data intelligence layer for buildings and electric grid operators, and help remove any guesswork from the implementation of optimized electricity demand response. Better demand response means that less efficient, and often more expensive, forms of electricity generation do not need to come online during times of high electricity demand. Demand response optimization reduces the stress on transmission and distribution systems, making them less likely to fail. A well implemented demand response program leads to competitive and efficient wholesale electricity market operations, and helps in keeping electricity prices in check.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop, deploy, and evaluate innovative algorithms and software for control-oriented predictive modeling for energy systems, with specific application to electricity demand response. There are four significant technical hurdles that will be addressed by the proposed effort: (a) modeling complexity and heterogeneity, (b) limitations of rule-based demand response, (c) control complexity and scalability, and (d) interpretability of modeling and control. The goal of the proposed research is to address each of the technological hurdles, and in doing so develop (i) data-driven control oriented modeling tools for demand response and for large scale energy systems, and (ii) a methodology to preserve interpretability of our data-driven control-oriented models for providing energy analytics to the facilities manager based on real-world data. The proposed project will include pilot deployments on real buildings to evaluate the performance of the demand response software.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this proposal is to develop a demand-side energy management software product called DR-Advisor. DR-Advisor (Demand Response-Advisor) is a data-driven Demand Response (DR) recommendation system. It builds predictive models of a building based on historical weather, schedule, set-points and electricity consumption data, while also learning from the actions of the building operator. These models are then used for synthesizing recommendations about the control actions that the operator needs to take, during a demand response event, to obtain the most load curtailment while providing guarantees on occupant comfort and operations. DR-Advisor provides real-time visibility to the available curtailment for better response for the participants and better dispatch for the grid operators. Applications of the proposed research includes improved demand response participation; optimal DR dispatch for utilities, curtailment service providers (CSPs), and grid operators; system level optimization and data-driven control approaches for supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) systems; building efficiency and smart energy management.

Intellectual Merit

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project developed, deployed, and evaluated innovative algorithms and software for control-oriented predictive modeling for energy systems, with applications in demand response for large commercial buildings. There are four significant technical hurdles that were addressed by the effort.

1.  Modeling complexity and heterogeneity: Unlike the automobile or the aircraft industry, each building is designed and used in a different way and therefore, it must be uniquely modeled. 

2.  Limitations of rule-based demand response: Current rule-based and pre-determined demand response strategies do not account for the state of the building but are instead ad hoc, based on best practices and rules of thumb.

3.  Control complexity and scalability: Upon receiving a notification for a DR event, the building’s facilities manager must determine an appropriate DR strategy to achieve the required load curtailment. In a large building, it is difficult to asses the effect of one control action on other sub-systems and on the building’s overall power consumption because the building sub-systems are tightly coupled.

4. Interpretability of modeling and control: Predictive models for buildings, regardless how sophisticated, lose their effectiveness unless they can be interpreted by human experts and facilities managers in the field. Therefore, the required solution must be transparent, human centric and highly interpretable.

The project addressed each of the technological hurdles successfully. DR-Advisor enables customers to monitor and respond to wholesale electricity market price signals when it is cost-effective for them to do so. The following are the intellectual contributions of the proposed research:

1.  Data-driven control oriented modeling tools for demand response and for large scale energy systems: We propose a novel control and optimization algorithms which used machine learning approaches to rapidly create suitable models using only the building's operational data. The resultant algorithms were able to predict building power consumption with 93%-98% accuracy and reduce operational costs through demand response, increased energy efficiency and reduced demand charges. This work lies at the intersection of machine learning and control synthesis, and bridges the gap between the two disciplines with applications in demand response.

2.  Interactive energy analytics engine for SCADA systems: We developed a methodology to preserve interpretability of our data-driven control-oriented models for providing energy analytics, beyond demand response, to the facilities manager based on data.

3.  The proposed research plan included the development, and pilot deployments of the DR-Advisor software on real buildings. A successful and a thorough evaluation of the proposed technology have successfully taken us on the path to paid customers and scalable commercialization. 

Broader Impact:

This project developed fundamental contributions to bridge machine learning and control of physical plants. Using our technology, commercial building operators  will see lower and more predictable electric bills. Building operators will utilize our predictive control technologies to more efficiently operate their buildings and participate in Demand Response with little effort and peace of mind. Utilities and grid operators will see increased participation in Demand Response and Peak Load Shedding programs that can result in a less stressed, more reliable, and greener grid.

Our core technology is faster and cheaper than current industry modeling practices by several orders of magnitude and is compatible with the majority of commercial buildings around the world. We bridge machine learning with control systems- two traditionally disparate fields - and can use our practical application knowledge to advance scientific understanding in both.

The control and optimization techniques developed in this project are applicable to the control of physical plants with slow dynamics. 

 

Background:

Demand response (DR) is critical as the volatility on the grid continues to increase.  For e.g., in January 2014, the average price of energy in the US East Coast (PJM Wholesale Market) was $31/MWh and shot up to $2,680/MWh -  an 86X increase! DR is a cleaner, reliable, and cost-effect means of mitigating peak conditions that jeopardize the reliability of the electricity grid.
